text: Maiden’s Fanciful Wish

⸤How I wish that you were my little brother⸥,\f + \fr 8:1 \ft Literally “O that he would give you like a brother to me” \f*\f + \fr 8:1 \ft The Hebrew construction (which is somewhat misleading if rendered in a woodenly literal sense) is an idiom expressing one’s fanciful wish \f*
\add who\add* nursed ⸤upon my mother’s breasts⸥!\f + \fr 8:1 \ft Literally “at the breast of my mother” \f*
\add If\add* ⸤I met you outside⸥,\f + \fr 8:1 \ft Literally “I will find you in the street” \f* I would kiss you,
⸤and no one would despise me⸥!\f + \fr 8:1 \ft Literally “also they would not despise me” \f*

⸤I would surely bring you⸥\f + \fr 8:2 \ft Literally “I would lead you and I would bring you” \f*\f + \fr 8:2 \ft The combination of the two verbs creates a hendiadys which may be rendered more cogently as “I would surely bring you …” \f* to the house of my mother,
⸤who would surely teach me⸥;\f + \fr 8:2 \ft Literally “she will teach me” \f*
⸤I would give you spiced wine to drink⸥,\f + \fr 8:2 \ft Literally “I would give you to drink from the wine of the spice” \f*

the ⸤sweet wine⸥\f + \fr 8:2 \ft Or “juice” \f* of my pomegranates.\f + \fr 8:2 \ft The traditional Hebrew reads the singular “my pomegranate.” However, the plural reading “my pomegranates” is attested in numerous medieval Hebrew manuscripts and is reflected in the ancient versions (Greek Septuagint, Aramaic Targum, Syriac Peshitta). The latter makes the most sense in this context as a euphemistic description of the maiden’s delights \f*
Double Refrain: Embrace and Adjuration
His left \add hand is\add* under my head,
and his right \add hand\add* embraces\f + \fr 8:3 \ft Or “embraced” \f* me.
I adjure you, ⸤O maidens of Jerusalem⸥,\f + \fr 8:4 \ft Literally “O daughters of Jerusalem” \f*

do not\f + \fr 8:4 \ft Or “Why must you … before it pleases?” \f* arouse or awaken love until it pleases!\f + \fr 8:4 \ft Or “Do not stir up or awaken the love until it is willing,” or “Do not disturb or interrupt \fq our \ft lovemaking until it is satisfied” \f*
Up from the Wilderness and under the Apple Tree
Who \add is\add* this coming up from the wilderness,
leaning upon her beloved?
Under the apple tree I awakened you;
there your mother ⸤conceived you⸥;\f + \fr 8:5 \ft Literally “was in labor with you” \f*
there she who was in labor gave birth to you.
The Nature of Genuine Romantic Love
Set me as a seal upon your heart,
as a seal upon your arm;
for love \add is\add* strong as death;
passion \add is\add* fierce as Sheol;
its flashes \add are\add* flashes of fire;
\add it is\add* a blazing flame.
Many waters cannot quench love;
rivers cannot sweep it away.\f + \fr 8:7 \ft Or “and rivers cannot engulf it” \f*
If a man were to give all the wealth of his house ⸤for love⸥,\f + \fr 8:7 \ft Literally “in the love” \f*
he would be utterly scorned.\f + \fr 8:7 \ft Literally “they will utterly scorn him” \f*
Maiden’s Virtuous Chastity and Voluptuous Beauty
⸤We have a little sister⸥,\f + \fr 8:8 \ft Literally “a little sister for us” \f*
⸤and she does not yet have any breasts⸥.\f + \fr 8:8 \ft Literally “and there is no breast for her” \f*
What should we do for our sister
⸤on the day when she is betrothed⸥?\f + \fr 8:8 \ft Literally “on the day when it is spoken of her” \f*\f + \fr 8:8 \ft Or “on the day when she is spoken for” \f*
If she \add is\add* a wall,

⸤we will adorn her with a turret of silver⸥;\f + \fr 8:9 \ft Literally “we will build upon her a camp of silver” \f*\f + \fr 8:9 \ft The term translated “turret” refers to the decorative parapet adorning the top of a building. This image is likely figurative for a silver tiara set upon the head \f*
but if she \add is\add* a door,
we will barricade her with boards of cedar.\f + \fr 8:9 \ft Or “we will enclose her” \f*
I \add was\add* a wall, and my breasts \add were\add* like the towers,
⸤so \add my betrothed\add* viewed me with great delight⸥.\f + \fr 8:10 \ft Literally “then I was in his eyes as \fq one who \ft finds peace” \f*
Solomon’s Vineyard and the Maiden’s Gift
⸤Solomon had a vineyard⸥\f + \fr 8:11 \ft Literally “A vineyard was for Solomon” \f* at Baal-hamon;
⸤he entrusted his vineyard to the keepers⸥;\f + \fr 8:11 \ft Literally “he gave the vineyard to the keepers” \f*
⸤people paid a thousand silver \add pieces\add* for its fruit⸥.\f + \fr 8:11 \ft Literally “each one brought a thousand silver \fq pieces \ft for his fruit” \f*
⸤My own “vineyard” belongs to me⸥;\f + \fr 8:12 \ft Literally “My vineyard that for me before my face” \f*
the “thousand” are for you, O Solomon,
⸤and “two hundred” for those who tend its fruit⸥.\f + \fr 8:12 \ft Literally “and two hundred for \fq the \ft keepers \fq of \ft his fruit” \f*
Closing Words of Mutual Love
O you who dwell in the garden,
\add my\add* companions are listening to your voice.
Let me hear \add it\add*!
Flee, my beloved!
⸤Be like a gazelle⸥\f + \fr 8:14 \ft Literally “and be like for you to a gazelle” \f* or ⸤a young stag⸥\f + \fr 8:14 \ft Literally “to the fawn of the stag” \f*
upon ⸤the perfumed mountains⸥!\f + \fr 8:14 \ft Literally “the mountains of spices” \f*
